title: Global Sensitivity Analysis of a simple Gaussian model
text: Global Sensitivity Analysis goal breaking mathematical model‚Äôs tough rind, allowing us look inside. Let‚Äôs assume modeling problem two quantities interest, ùêò={Y1,Y2}\mathbf{Y} = \{Y_1, Y_2\}, defined function three variables, ùêó=(X1,X2,X3)\mathbf{X} = (X_1, X_2, X_3). express dependence linear transformation ùêò=Aùêó\mathbf{Y} = \mathbf{X}, =[42325‚àí1]. = \begin{bmatrix}       4 & 2 & 3 \\       2 & 5 & -1      \end{bmatrix}.  assume inputs uncertain uncertainty can modeled using multivariate normal distribution, ùêó‚àºùí©(ùõç,Œ£)\mathbf{X} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{\mu}, \Sigma), Œº=(1,1,1)\mu = (1,1,1) Œ£=[10.50.50.510.50.50.51]. \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix}             1 & 0.5 & 0.5 \\             0.5 & 1 & 0.5 \\             0.5 & 0.5 & 1           \end{bmatrix}.  perform uncertainty quantification model, assumed distribution inputs, can use simple Monte Carlo simulation. generate input sample (x), estimate model output (y) input. can define model simulate R using following code block. can plot distribution output using ggplot2 package.
code: # Define the input distribution parameters mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  # Define the number of samples N <- 1000  # Set the random number generator seed for reproducibility set.seed(777)  # Sample from standard normals x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  # Transform the standard normals into the required distribution x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  # Define the model (matrix with coefficients) A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)  # Generate the output y <- t(A %*% t(x)) colnames(y) <- c("y1", "y2") library(ggplot2) library(patchwork)  # Set the theme theme_set(theme_minimal())  # Prepare the marginal and the 2D density plots p1 <- ggplot(as.data.frame(y), aes(x = y1, y = y2)) +   geom_point(color = "black") p2 <- ggplot(as.data.frame(y), aes(x = y1)) +   geom_density() p3 <- ggplot(as.data.frame(y), aes(x = y2)) +   geom_density() +   coord_flip()  p2 + plot_spacer() + p1 + p3 +   plot_layout(ncol = 2, nrow = 2, widths = c(4, 1), heights = c(1, 4), axes = "collect")

title: Global Sensitivity Analysis of a simple Gaussian model
text: Given uncertainty, interested knowing important inputs model. goal package gsaot designed . package, can compute different indices evaluate importance inputs different statistical properties output. Let‚Äôs first compute Wasserstein-Bures sensitivity indices. Since inputs outputs gaussians, indices actual solution Optimal Transport problem . However, usually case. hyperparameter needed case number partitions input data, M. set value 25 since 1000 data points. can also use package functions create plots indices.  estimate uncertainty indices, can use bootstrapping. implemented function ot_indices_wb option boot = TRUE. case, also set number replicas (R).
code: library(gsaot)  M <- 25 indices_wb <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M) indices_wb #> Method: wass-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        V1        V2        V3  #> 0.4951390 0.5072342 0.1387523  #>  #> Advective component: #>        V1        V2        V3  #> 0.3030834 0.3214758 0.1209107  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>        V1        V2        V3  #> 0.1920556 0.1857584 0.0178415 plot(indices_wb) # Enable bootstrap boot <- TRUE # Set the number of replicas R <- 100 # Define the confidence level conf <- 0.99 # Define the type of confidence interval type <- "norm"  # Compute the indices indices_wb <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M,                              boot = boot, R = R, conf = conf, type = type) plot(indices_wb)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Leonardo Chiani. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Emanuele Borgonovo. Reviewer. Elmar Plischke. Reviewer. Massimo Tavoni. Reviewer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Chiani, Leonardo, Borgonovo, Emanuele, Plischke, Elmar, Tavoni, Massimo (2025). ‚Äúgsaot: R package Optimal Transport-based sensitivity analysis.‚Äù arXiv preprint arXiv:2507.18588.
code: @Article{,   title = {gsaot: an R package for Optimal Transport-based sensitivity analysis},   author = {{Chiani} and {Leonardo} and {Borgonovo} and {Emanuele} and {Plischke} and {Elmar} and {Tavoni} and {Massimo}},   journal = {arXiv preprint arXiv:2507.18588},   year = {2025}, }

what: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: package gsaot provides set tools compute plot Optimal Transport (OT) based sensitivity indices. core functions package : ot_indices(): compute OT indices multivariate outputs using different solvers OT (network simplex, Sinkhorn, ). ot_indices_wb(): compute OT indices univariate multivariate outputs using Wasserstein-Bures semi-metric. ot_indices_1d(): compute OT indices univariate outputs using OT solution one dimension. package also provides functions plot resulting indices separation measures.

title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: can install development version gsaot GitHub :
code: install.packages("gsaot") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("pietrocipolla/gsaot")

title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: sinkhorn sinkhorn_log solvers gsaot greatly benefit optimization compilation. add option (package installation), edit .R/Makevars file desired flags. Even though different compilers different options, common flag enable safe level optimization detailed information customize R packages compilation can found R guide.
code: CXXFLAGS+=-O2

title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: can use gaussian toy model three outputs example: defined number partitions, compute sensitivity indices using different solvers. First, Sinkhorn solver default parameters: Second, Network Simplex solver: Third, Wasserstein-Bures solver, bootstrap: Fourth, can use package compute sensitivity map output:
code: library(gsaot)  N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x) M <- 25  sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M) sensitivity_indices #> Method: sinkhorn  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.6040598 0.6304113 0.2817856 sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M, solver = "transport") sensitivity_indices #> Method: transport  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.5135492 0.5274847 0.1734944 sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M, boot = TRUE, R = 100) sensitivity_indices #> Method: wass-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.4833691 0.4940299 0.1097725  #>  #> Advective component: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.2943062 0.3174669 0.1018953  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>          X1          X2          X3  #> 0.189062870 0.176562994 0.007877195  #>  #> Type of confidence interval: norm  #> Number of replicates: 100  #> Confidence level: 0.95  #> Bootstrap statistics: #>   input  component   original        bias      low.ci    high.ci #> 1    X1 wass-bures 0.49284730 0.009478185 0.465069799 0.50166843 #> 2    X2 wass-bures 0.50378617 0.009756254 0.479159970 0.50889985 #> 3    X3 wass-bures 0.12863517 0.018862723 0.087497514 0.13204739 #> 4    X1  advective 0.29925643 0.004950185 0.282197530 0.30641496 #> 5    X2  advective 0.32163503 0.004168111 0.308057464 0.32687637 #> 6    X3  advective 0.11239018 0.010494927 0.083363925 0.12042659 #> 7    X1  diffusive 0.19359087 0.004528000 0.181197928 0.19692781 #> 8    X2  diffusive 0.18215114 0.005588143 0.169509166 0.18361682 #> 9    X3  diffusive 0.01624499 0.008367797 0.002543453 0.01321094 sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices_smap(x, y, M) sensitivity_indices #>             X1         X2        X3 #> [1,] 0.5865925 0.04945865 0.2004293 #> [2,] 0.3221281 0.71433091 0.1206923

what: Compute confidence intervals for sensitivity indices ‚Äî confint.gsaot_indices
title: Compute confidence intervals for sensitivity indices ‚Äî confint.gsaot_indices
text: Computes confidence intervals gsaot_indices object using bootstrap results.

title: Compute confidence intervals for sensitivity indices ‚Äî confint.gsaot_indices
code: # S3 method for class 'gsaot_indices' confint(object, parm = NULL, level = 0.95, type = "norm", ...)

title: Compute confidence intervals for sensitivity indices ‚Äî confint.gsaot_indices
text: object object class gsaot_indices, bootstrap results included. parm specification parameters given confidence intervals, either vector numbers vector names. missing, parameters considered. level (default 0.95) Confidence level interval. type (default "norm") Method compute confidence interval. information, check type option boot::boot.ci(). ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Compute confidence intervals for sensitivity indices ‚Äî confint.gsaot_indices
text: data frame following columns: input: Name input variable. component: index component Wasserstein-Bures. index: Estimated indices original: Original estimates. bias: Bootstrap bias estimate. low.ci: Lower bound confidence interval. high.ci: Upper bound confidence interval.

title: Compute confidence intervals for sensitivity indices ‚Äî confint.gsaot_indices

what: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
title: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
text: Calculate entropic lower bounds entropic Optimal Transport sensitivity indices

title: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
code: entropic_bound(   y,   M,   cost = "L2",   discrete_out = FALSE,   solver = "sinkhorn",   solver_optns = NULL,   scaling = TRUE )

title: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
text: y array matrix containing output values. M scalar representing number partitions continuous inputs. cost (default "L2") string function defining cost function Optimal Transport problem. "L2" function taking input y returning cost matrix. cost="L2", ot_indices uses squared Euclidean metric. discrete_out (default FALSE) Logical, default output sample y equally weighted. discrete_out=TRUE, function tries create histogram realizations use histogram weights. works output discrete mixed number realizations large. advantage option reduce dimension cost matrix. solver Solver Optimal Transport problem. Currently supported options : "sinkhorn" (default), Sinkhorn's solver (Cuturi 2013) . "sinkhorn_log", Sinkhorn's solver log scale (Peyr√© et al. 2019) . solver_optns (optional) list containing options Optimal Transport solver. See details allowed options default ones. scaling (default TRUE) Logical sets whether scale cost matrix.

title: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
text: scalar representing entropic lower bound.

title: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
text: function allows computation entropic lower bounds. solver either "sinkhorn" "sinkhorn_log".

title: Entropic lower bounds for entropic optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî entropic_bound
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  M <- 25  sink_lb <- entropic_bound(y, M)

what: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun
title: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun
text: Generates samples multivariate Gaussian distribution evaluates simple linear transformation model.

title: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun
code: gaussian_fun(N)

title: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun
text: N Number input samples generate.

title: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun
text: list two elements: x: numeric matrix size N x 8 containing input samples. y: numeric vector length N corresponding function outputs.

title: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun
text: Inputs x sampled : $$ \mathbf{X} \sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \Sigma), \quad \boldsymbol{\mu} = [1, 1, 1], \quad \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0.5 & 0.5 \\ 0.5 & 1 & 0.5 \\ 0.5 & 0.5 & 1 \end{bmatrix} $$ output given : $$ \mathbf{Y} = \mathbf{X}^{\top}, \quad = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & 5 & -1 \end{bmatrix} $$

title: Multivariate Gaussian linear model evaluation ‚Äî gaussian_fun

what: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
title: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
text: Calculate irrelevance threshold using dummy variable Optimal Transport sensitivity indices

title: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
code: irrelevance_threshold(   y,   M,   dummy_optns = NULL,   cost = "L2",   discrete_out = FALSE,   solver = "sinkhorn",   solver_optns = NULL,   scaling = TRUE )

title: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
text: y array matrix containing output values. M scalar representing number partitions continuous inputs. dummy_optns (default NULL) list containing options distribution dummy variable. See details information. cost (default "L2") string function defining cost function Optimal Transport problem. "L2" function taking input y returning cost matrix. cost="L2", ot_indices uses squared Euclidean metric. discrete_out (default FALSE) Logical, default output sample y equally weighted. discrete_out=TRUE, function tries create histogram realizations use histogram weights. works output discrete mixed number realizations large. advantage option reduce dimension cost matrix. solver Solver Optimal Transport problem. Currently supported options : "1d", one-dimensional analytic solution. "wasserstein-bures", Wasserstein-Bures solution. "sinkhorn" (default), Sinkhorn's solver (Cuturi 2013) . "sinkhorn_log", Sinkhorn's solver log scale (Peyr√© et al. 2019) . "transport", solver non regularized OT problem using transport::transport(). solver_optns (optional) list containing options Optimal Transport solver. See details allowed options default ones. scaling (default TRUE) Logical sets whether scale cost matrix.

title: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
text: object class gsaot_indices.

title: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
text: function allows computation irrelevance threshold. function samples distribution defined dummy_optns (default standard normal), independent output y computes indices using algorithm specified solver. hood, lower_bound calls available functions package: ot_indices_1d() (solver="1d") ot_indices_wb() (solver="wasserstein-bures") ot_indices() (solver %% c("sinkhorn", "sinkhorn_log", "wasserstein")) user can choose distribution dummy variable using argument dummy_optns. dummy_optns named list least term called "distr" defining sampling function. terms list used arguments sampling function.

title: Irrelevance threshold for optimal transport sensitivity indices ‚Äî irrelevance_threshold
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  M <- 25  dummy_lb <- irrelevance_threshold(y, M)  # Custom sampling funtion and network simplex solver dummy_optns <- list(distr = "rgamma", shape = 3) dummy_lb_cust <- irrelevance_threshold(y, M,                                       dummy_optns = dummy_optns,                                       solver = "transport")

title: Ishigami-Homma function evaluation ‚Äî ishi_homma_fun

text: N Number input samples generate. (default: 2) Numeric, amplitude second sine component . B (default: 1) Numeric, coefficient interaction term.

title: Ishigami-Homma function evaluation ‚Äî ishi_homma_fun
text: list two elements: x: numeric matrix size N x 8 containing input samples. y: numeric vector length N corresponding function outputs.

title: Ishigami-Homma function evaluation ‚Äî ishi_homma_fun
text: Ishigami-Homma function defined : $$Y = \sin(X_1) + \cdot \sin^2(X_2) + B \cdot X_3^4 \cdot \sin(X_1)$$ \(X_i \sim \mathcal{U}(-\pi, \pi)\).

what: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
text: ot_indices calculates sensitivity indices using Optimal Transport (OT) multivariate output sample y respect input data x. Sensitivity indices measure influence inputs outputs, values ranging 0 1.

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
code: ot_indices(   x,   y,   M,   cost = "L2",   discrete_out = FALSE,   solver = "sinkhorn",   solver_optns = NULL,   scaling = TRUE,   boot = FALSE,   stratified_boot = TRUE,   R = NULL,   parallel = "no",   ncpus = 1,   conf = 0.95,   type = "norm" )

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
text: x matrix data.frame containing input(s) values. values can numeric, factors, strings. type data changes partitioning. values continuous (double), function partitions data M sets. values discrete (integers, strings, factors), number partitioning sets data-driven. y matrix containing output values. column represents different output variable, row represents different observation. numeric values allowed. M scalar representing number partitions continuous inputs. cost (default "L2") string function defining cost function Optimal Transport problem. "L2" function taking input y returning cost matrix. cost="L2", ot_indices uses squared Euclidean metric. discrete_out (default FALSE) Logical, default output sample y equally weighted. discrete_out=TRUE, function tries create histogram realizations use histogram weights. works output discrete mixed number realizations large. advantage option reduce dimension cost matrix. solver Solver Optimal Transport problem. Currently supported options : "sinkhorn" (default), Sinkhorn's solver (Cuturi 2013) . "sinkhorn_log", Sinkhorn's solver log scale (Peyr√© et al. 2019) . "transport", solver non regularized OT problem using transport::transport(). solver_optns (optional) list containing options Optimal Transport solver. See details allowed options default ones. scaling (default TRUE) Logical sets whether scale cost matrix. boot (default FALSE) Logical sets whether perform bootstrapping OT indices. stratified_boot (default TRUE) Logical sets type resampling performed. stratified_boot=FALSE, function resamples dataset creates partitions. Otherwise, first, creates partitions performs stratified bootstrapping strata partitions. R (default NULL) Positive integer, number bootstrap replicas. parallel (default "") type parallel operation used (). missing, default taken option boot.parallel (set, ""). considered boot = TRUE. information, check boot::boot() function. ncpus (default 1) Positive integer: number processes used parallel operation: typically one chose number available CPUs. Check ncpus option boot::boot() function boot package. conf (default 0.95) Number 0 1 representing default confidence level. considered boot = TRUE. Different confidence levels can computed postprocessing using confint.gsaot_indices(). type (default "norm") Method compute default confidence interval. considered boot = TRUE. information, check type argument boot::boot.ci(). Different confidence intervals can computed postprocessing using confint.gsaot_indices().

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
text: gsaot_indices object containing: method: string identifies type indices computed. indices: names array containing sensitivity indices 0 1 column x, indicating influence input variable output variables. bound: double representing upper bound separation measure array representing mean separation input according bootstrap replicas. x, y: input output data provided arguments function. inner_statistic: list matrices containing values inner statistics partitions defined partitions. method = wasserstein-bures, matrix three rows containing Wasserstein-Bures indices, Advective, Diffusive components. partitions: matrix containing partitions built calculate sensitivity indices. column contains partition associated column x. boot = TRUE, object contains also: indices_ci: data.frame first column input, second third columns lower upper bound confidence interval. inner_statistic_ci: list matrices. element list contains lower upper confidence bounds partition defined row. bound_ci: list containing lower upper bounds confidence intervals separation measure bound. type, conf: type confidence interval confidence level, provided arguments. W_boot: list bootstrap objects, one input.

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
text: OT widely studied topic Operational Research Calculus. reference OT solvers package Peyr√© et al. (2019) . default solver "sinkhorn", Sinkhorn's solver introduced Cuturi (2013) . solves entropic-regularized version OT problem. "sinkhorn_log" solves OT problem log scale. stable low values regularization parameter slower converge. option "transport" used choose solver non-regularized OT problem. hood, function calls transport::transport() package transport. option define solver per se, solver defined argument solver_optns. See next section information.

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
text: argument solver_optns empty (default options) list required solver parameters. parameters included list set default values. solvers "sinkhorn" "sinkhorn_log" options: numIterations (default 1e3): positive integer defining maximum number Sinkhorn's iterations allowed. solver converge number iterations set, solver throw error. epsilon (default 0.01): positive real number defining regularization coefficient. value low, solver may return NA. maxErr (default 1e-9): positive real number defining approximation error threshold marginal histogram partition one computed solver. solver may fail converge numIterations value low. solver "transport" parameters: method (default "networkflow): string defining solver OT problem. control: named list parameters chosen method result call transport::trcontrol(). threads (default 1): Integer specifying number threads used parallel computing. details regarding solver, check transport::transport() help page.

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
text: Cuturi M (2013). ‚ÄúSinkhorn distances: Lightspeed computation optimal transport.‚Äù Advances neural information processing systems, 26. Peyr√© G, Cuturi M, others (2019). ‚ÄúComputational optimal transport: applications data science.‚Äù Foundations Trends¬Æ Machine Learning, 11(5-6), 355‚Äì607.

title: Estimate optimal transport sensitivity indices for generic outputs ‚Äî ot_indices
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x)  M <- 25  # Calculate sensitivity indices sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M) sensitivity_indices #> Method: sinkhorn  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.5627428 0.6354905 0.2735419

title: Estimate Wasserstein-Bures approximation of the optimal transport solution ‚Äî ot_indices_wb
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x) y <- y  ot_indices_wb(x, y, 10) #> Method: wass-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.4558156 0.4650694 0.1258777  #>  #> Advective component: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.2862736 0.3033568 0.1100902  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>         X1         X2         X3  #> 0.16954200 0.16171258 0.01578748

code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x)  M <- 25  # Calculate sensitivity indices ind_wb <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M) ind_sink <- ot_indices(x, y, M)  plot_comparison(list(ind_wb, ind_sink))

text: Solved compatibility issue ggplot2 4.0.0 Solved bug solver="sinkhorn_log"

title: gsaot 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-07-18 Added confint() method class gsaot_indices Added bootstrap data gsaot_indices objects

title: gsaot 1.0.1
text: Added summary() method class gsaot_indices plot_comparison(), added checks inputs titles title style

title: gsaot 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-06-17 plot_functions(), changed y axis label consistency theory Split lower_bound() entropic_bound() irrelevance_threshold() two use cases previously identified "bound". plot_separations(), changed label y-axis "Separation Measurements" print.gsaot_indices(), removed upper bound display ot_indices_bw(), changed names indices ot_indices(), removed checks y cost!="L2" Added plot_comparison() graphically compare different indices print.gsaot_indices() output simplified ot_indices(), ot_indices_1d(), ot_indices_wb() now work correctly NAs input

title: gsaot 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-04-21 ot_indices(), improved solver sinkhorn_log. lower_bound() improved documentation. ot_indices_1d() now allows use different L_p^p norms. ot_indices(), ot_indices_1d(), ot_indices_wb() extended bootstrap output. plot_separations() new name plot_inner_stats().

title: gsaot 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-01-10 Added NEWS.md file track changes package. Initial CRAN submission.
